column4: How can I recreate a swap partition for an existing Ubuntu easily and safely?
why / how did you delete it
I was having 2 distro (ubuntu and 64 studio) 64 studio installed on 2nd partition, and ubuntu installed on 1st after i installed 64studio
and i can see there are 2 swap partitions in the harddisk at the end of it.
great, so you've not got a problem
but i deleted a smaller one, now i've got a larger one here. and Ubuntu's still working, but there's a problem:
I deleted the 64studio partition, one swap partition, and install debian (with no bootloader)
but when i restart, ubuntu loads ok (at the bootsplash) but then it switch to Terminal.
and says there's a problem with filesystem, and suggest i should manually correct it.
but after i type exit, it went on perfectly normal and boot gdm well.
I'll say it again - what makes you think there is a problem with the swap partition
I thought the swap i deleted was this distro's swap hahah, i'm quite a noob ya know.
and I deleted one that's all.
I suggest you just re-install to get a clean base as its clear you a.) can't read the error messages properly b.) don't really understand whats going on
So what's the main problem? The file system? hmm.. how should I correcnt this?
Hmm a clean base'd do. Okay, thanks mate.
